name: Saffron Finch
description: Named for the yellow coloration of adult males, females are less striking, more greenish.
spread_note: Lowlands of South America, from Ecuador to southern Argentina, excluding the Amazon
proportions: Body length 6–7 cm; tail length 6 cm; wing length 8 cm; weight 20–25 g
attractions: During nesting season, the male emits a pleasant, though somewhat monotonous, song. The saffron finch builds a deep, bowl-shaped nest in various cavities, sometimes taking over a potter bird’s nest or settling under a roof. Parents initially feed chicks only insects, later adding digested seeds.
breeding: We have kept saffron finches since 2002, with nesting beginning in 2005.
